Pivot Concept Relationships

Source: vignettes/pivot-concept-relationships.Rmd
pivot-concept-relationships.Rmd
library(chariot)
library(tidyverse)
conn <- connectAthena()

Pivoting the Concept Relationship table can provide a rich array representing the various relationships an OMOP Concept may have.

To exemplify, a test dataset of RxNorm and RxNorm Extension concepts are retrieved.

test_data <- 
  get_test_drug_concepts(conn = conn)
#> [2021-01-10 16:07:11]    Overriding cache... Querying Athena...
#> [2021-01-10 16:07:11]    
#> ✓ Open connection
#> [2021-01-10 16:07:11]    
#> ✓ JDBC connection
#> [2021-01-10 16:07:11]    SQL: SELECT * FROM omop_vocabulary.concept c WHERE c.invalid_reason IS NULL AND c.vocabulary_id IN ('RxNorm', 'RxNorm Extension') AND c.standard_concept <> 'C' AND c.domain_id = 'Drug' ORDER BY RANDOM() LIMIT 100
#> [2021-01-10 16:07:11]    Querying...
#> [2021-01-10 16:07:14]    Querying...complete
#> [2021-01-10 16:07:14]    
#> ✓ Returned data has more than 0 rows
#> [2021-01-10 16:07:14]    Caching resultset...
test_data
#> # A tibble: 100 x 10
#>    concept_id concept_name domain_id vocabulary_id concept_class_id
#>         <dbl> <chr>        <chr>     <chr>         <chr>           
#>  1   43185540 2 ML Acyclo… Drug      RxNorm Exten… Quant Branded D…
#>  2   41357611 5 ML Vindes… Drug      RxNorm Exten… Quant Clinical …
#>  3   41027523 ropinirole … Drug      RxNorm Exten… Branded Drug Box
#>  4   43281802 Epinephrine… Drug      RxNorm Exten… Branded Drug

The relationships of these concepts are derived.

test_data_relationships <- lookup_relationships(test_data$concept_id,
                                                conn = conn)
#> [2021-01-10 16:07:15]    
#> ✓ Open connection
#> [2021-01-10 16:07:15]    
#> ✓ JDBC connection
#> [2021-01-10 16:07:15]    
#> ✓ Returned data has more than 0 rows
#> [2021-01-10 16:07:16]    
#> ✓ Open connection
#> [2021-01-10 16:07:16]    
#> ✓ JDBC connection
#> [2021-01-10 16:07:17]    
#> ✓ Returned data has more than 0 rows

#> #   concept_name_2 <chr>, domain_id_2 <chr>, vocabulary_id_2 <chr>,
#> #   concept_class_id_2 <chr>, standard_concept_2 <chr>, concept_code_2 <chr>,
#> #   valid_start_date_2 <date>, valid_end_date_2 <date>, invalid_reason_2 <chr>

To properly pivot the resultset, the concepts on both sides require transformation into a single cell per concept. This is achieved by converting concepts into the strip format.

test_data_relationships2 <-
  test_data_relationships %>%
  merge_strip(into = "concept_1", 
              suffix = "_1") %>%
  merge_strip(into = "concept_2",
              suffix = "_2")
test_data_relationships2
#> # A tibble: 878 x 5
#>    concept_2_id concept_2         concept_1_id concept_1         relationship_id
#>           <dbl> <chr>                    <dbl> <chr>             <chr>          
#>  1     19082103 [V] [N] 19082103…     43868467 [V] [S] 43868467… RxNorm has dos…
#>  2     43850272 [V] [S] 43850272…     43868467 [V] [S] 43868467… Has marketed f…
#>  3     43868467 [V] [S] 43868467…     43868467 [V] [S] 43868467… Mapped from    
#>  4     43868467 [V] [S] 43868467…     43868467 [V] [S] 43868467… Maps to        
#>  5      1539411 [V] [S] 1539411 …     44126900 [V] [S] 44126900… Marketed form …
#>  6     19082573 [V] [N] 19082573…     44126900 [V] [S] 44126900… RxNorm has dos…
#>  7     44024676 [V] [N] 44024676…     44126900 [V] [S] 44126900… Has supplier   
#>  8     44126900 [V] [S] 44126900…     44126900 [V] [S] 44126900… Mapped from    
#>  9     44126900 [V] [S] 44126900…     44126900 [V] [S] 44126900… Maps to        
#> 10     43128942 [V] [N] 43128942…     43868467 [V] [S] 43868467… Has brand name 
#> # … with 868 more rows

The dataset can now be pivoted by the relationship, hinging on concept_1, which are the concepts that were originally inputted.

output <-
  test_data_relationships2 %>%
  pivot_wider(id_cols = concept_1,
              names_from = relationship_id, 
              values_from = concept_2)
#> Warning: Values are not uniquely identified; output will contain list-cols.
#> * Use `values_fn = list` to suppress this warning.
#> * Use `values_fn = length` to identify where the duplicates arise
#> * Use `values_fn = {summary_fun}` to summarise duplicates
output
#> # A tibble: 100 x 24
#>    concept_1 `RxNorm has dos… `Has marketed f… `Mapped from` `Maps to`
#>    <chr>     <list>           <list>           <list>        <list>   
#>  1 [V] [S] … <chr [1]>        <chr [2]>        <chr [1]>     <chr [1]>
#>  2 [V] [S] … <chr [1]>        <NULL>           <chr [2]>     <chr [1]>
#>  3 [V] [S] … <chr [1]>        <NULL>           <chr [1]>     <chr [1]>
#>  4 [V] [S] … <chr [1]>        <chr [1]>        <chr [1]>     <chr [1]>
#>  5 [V] [S] … <chr [1]>        <chr [1]>        <chr [1]>     <chr [1]>
#>  6 [V] [S] … <NULL>           <NULL>           <chr [1]>     <chr [1]>
#>  7 [V] [S] … <chr [1]>        <NULL>           <chr [1]>     <chr [1]>
#>  8 [V] [S] … <chr [1]>        <NULL>           <chr [1]>     <chr [1]>
#>  9 [V] [S] … <chr [1]>        <NULL>           <chr [2]>     <chr [1]>
#> 10 [V] [S] … <chr [1]>        <NULL>           <chr [2]>     <chr [1]>
#> # … with 90 more rows, and 19 more variables: `Marketed form of` <list>, `Has
#> #   supplier` <list>, `Has brand name` <list>, `RxNorm is a` <list>,
#> #   Constitutes <list>, `Has quantified form` <list>, `Box of` <list>,
#> #   `Tradename of` <list>, `Has tradename` <list>, `RxNorm ing of` <list>,
#> #   `Quantified form of` <list>, `Consists of` <list>, `Available as
#> #   box` <list>, `Drug has drug class` <list>, `RxNorm has ing` <list>, `RxNorm
#> #   - Source eq` <list>, `Concept replaces` <list>, `RxNorm inverse is
#> #   a` <list>, `RxNorm - SNOMED eq` <list>

Since at times a concept_1 may have a specific relationship to more than 1 concept_2, a list-cols are returned in the output. To create a more readable output, an aggregate function on concept_2 must be supplied to convert multiple concept_2 values into a string of length 1.

output <-
  test_data_relationships2 %>%
  pivot_wider(id_cols = concept_1,
              names_from = relationship_id, 
              values_from = concept_2,
              # Add aggregate function
              values_fn = list(concept_2 = ~ paste(unique(.), collapse = "|"))
              )
output
#> # A tibble: 100 x 24
#>    concept_1 `RxNorm has dos… `Has marketed f… `Mapped from` `Maps to`
#>    <chr>     <chr>            <chr>            <chr>         <chr>    
#>  1 [V] [S] … [V] [N] 1908210… [V] [S] 4385027… [V] [S] 4386… [V] [S] …
#>  2 [V] [S] … [V] [N] 1908257… <NA>             [V] [S] 4412… [V] [S] …
#>  3 [V] [S] … [V] [N] 1912692… <NA>             [V] [S] 2049… [V] [S] …
#>  4 [V] [S] … [V] [N] 1908222… [V] [S] 4315256… [V] [S] 4318… [V] [S] …
#>  5 [V] [S] … [V] [N] 1908216… [V] [S] 2013439… [V] [S] 2013… [V] [S] …
#>  6 [V] [S] … <NA>             <NA>             [V] [S] 2044… [V] [S] …
#>  7 [V] [S] … [V] [N] 1908207… <NA>             [V] [S] 3576… [V] [S] …
#>  8 [V] [S] … [V] [N] 1900194… <NA>             [V] [S] 3576… [V] [S] …
#>  9 [V] [S] … [V] [N] 1908257… <NA>             [V] [S] 3585… [V] [S] …
#> 10 [V] [S] … [V] [N] 1908225… <NA>             [V] [S] 3605… [V] [S] …
#> # … with 90 more rows, and 19 more variables: `Marketed form of` <chr>, `Has
#> #   supplier` <chr>, `Has brand name` <chr>, `RxNorm is a` <chr>,
#> #   Constitutes <chr>, `Has quantified form` <chr>, `Box of` <chr>, `Tradename
#> #   of` <chr>, `Has tradename` <chr>, `RxNorm ing of` <chr>, `Quantified form
#> #   of` <chr>, `Consists of` <chr>, `Available as box` <chr>, `Drug has drug
#> #   class` <chr>, `RxNorm has ing` <chr>, `RxNorm - Source eq` <chr>, `Concept
#> #   replaces` <chr>, `RxNorm inverse is a` <chr>, `RxNorm - SNOMED eq` <chr>

The resulting dataset contains a row for each original concept provided with each relationship and concept/s it has the relationship to in a pipe-separated string.
